title: Great product! (with one caveat)
body:
I enjoy my Nanopresso and was excited about the upgrade of using pods, to enhance portability and simplify cleanup. The large quantity and percentage of very positive reviews seemed like confirmation and I ordered this without hesitation.
I was both confused and irritated when the adapter I ordered failed to function (would not pressurize and would often blow the foil seal off of the pods. I felt that there were too many reviews for this to be user experience and ordered a duplicate adapter, thinking that perhaps I had received a dud. Sure enough, the new version worked flawlessly and is exactly what I was looking for.
Side-by-side comparison revealed what appears to be an assembly error. It appears that the plate that is designed to sit against the foil on the pod may have been inverted on the original item, as it did not have the raised profile of the functional version.
So, that would be one one caveat. If you purchase and are having issues, there is a small possibility that the item you bought has a manufacturing error.
Overall, this adapter is great and I now use it almost exclusively, if I'm using my Nanopresso.

title: Broke After a Handful of Uses
body:
UPDATE July 2023:
Wacaco replaced the broken component on the pod adapter (I'll note that the replacement part took a while to ship and arrived smelling like a chemical factory) after which it worked for a couple of weeks until the pump mechanism on the main module completely failed and stopped holding pressure/pumping water at all, rendering the entire $110+ device useless. Given this, I'm not increasing my rating. It's a great idea/concept, but the execution/build quality is just abysmal, especially given the price point.

----------------------------------

I'll preface by saying that while my Nanopresso NS worked I really loved it, and if it hadn't broken I'd be leaving a very different review.

I bought this adapter to go with my Nanopresso and after a couple of weeks and a handful of uses, two large pieces of plastic spontaneously and simultaneously flaked off the portafilter component of the top. I finished pulling a shot, unscrewed the adapter to clean it, and out of the device fell a piece of plastic from the threaded attachment wall and the outflow nozzle itself, which had flaked directly across the attachment point.

On closer examination, the plastic on the component that shed these pieces looks really different from the plastic on the other components -- lighter and sort of dry/brittle looking. Putting aside the fact that this is sort of alarming for plastic materials that come into contact with hot water, it does suggest some kind of manufacturing flaw.

I am currently in contact with Wacaco trying to get a replacement part covered by the warranty. If that effort succeeds and the replacement part proves higher quality, I will update this review. For now obviously I cannot recommend the device.

title: Started leaking after about 80 capsules
body: This adapter worked as advertised for about the 80 capsules, and then started having issues. After inserting the capsule, the foil breaks on about pump #6 and then espresso starts to flow. At about the 80 capsule mark, it started failing, and water clear leaks out at about pump #5, maybe 5ml. On pump #6, the foil breaks and things are almost normal, but the leak means the rest of this capsule comes out weak and watery because some water bypasses the capsule and comes out the side. title: GREAT way to make wonderful espresso with less mess!
body:
Why is Amazon asking me to rate the "Warmth" of this item?!!
ANYway, this is a really great adapter which allows you to make Nespresso shots of your choice without the mess of the standard portafilter/basket and coffee grounds.
I wanted a quicker way to prepare espresso while on the road, and this is it! If I have plenty of time in the morning, I enjoy the ritual of using my little hand grinder and putting my own coffee beans in, grinding it just right, pouring it into the basket, and using the double-shot adapter for my Nanopresso to make a really great espresso. This is arguably the best quality coffee you're going to get. BUT, if you take the time to try out a few different Nespresso pods and get to know the differences, you'll be able to make some excellent espresso for yourself with minimal cleanup.
Pro Tip: Get the "Wacaco Nanopresso Case, Protective Case for Nanopresso with Adapter Ring and Large Water Tank from Barista Kit, Large Size" - this will give you extra space to place two cartridges in the bottom of the case, as well as one inside the water tank! Since Nespresso pods can get dented and damaged very easily, this seems like the most simple way to keep a few spares protected before use. If you recycle your pods, you can also put an empty one in the water tank to dispose of later.
Pro Tip #2: Nespresso sells a few types of pods which have a higher concentration in them - meaning that you can add hot water after pulling the shot, and it'll essentially give you a double shot using one pod! I can't verify the caffeine content, but the "Lungo" pods are made to create a 3.7oz "shot" and the standard pods are for 1.35oz shots. So just make one Lungo, add some hot water to it, then add your sweetener or creamer and you're all set!
Pro Tip #3: Buy your pods from a Nespresso store if possible. You'll find they are less often dented or damaged than those which are shipped.

I'd like to credit my coworker for letting me know that this little adapter existed - it's made our snobby espresso tendencies much more seamless! ;-)

Next, just make coffee the same way as you were making it before.

However, the design flaw I have found, which is really irritating, is the fact that while the silver ring is threaded the same as the old cap to screw into the body, the new cap has a different thread and so whilst the filter units appear to be similar enough to fit in either cap, my existing YELLOW cap does not fit into the silver ring part of the adapter set, meaning my YELLOW Nanopresso is now yellow AND black :(

Now to start my search for the perfect pod...

title: Didn't work for me. At first. Then I found a way.
body:
Modified from 1 star to 3 stars.

[Original 1 star review]
Unfortunately I could not make this work. I used original Nespresso pods and the original instructions. I tried 3 times, with same behavior:
- A little (1/4 of the) water pressed through, then it got stuck. No water came through after that, then the safety valves opened and sprinkled coffee everywhere, clothes, kitchen furniture, etc. Cleanup.
- Taking it apart revealed that the capsule lid was torn off and the coffee blocked the output.
- In addition, the kit got so strongly stuck on the Nanopresso body that one time it took 20 minutes to take it off.
Since this behavior seemed to be consistent, I decided to return it. I was afraid I ruin the Nanopresso body with it. This is pity since the Nanopresso works excellent with regular coffee otherwise, so I keep that together with the Barista kit (5 stars both). Just not recommended with Nespresso pods.

[Edit]
I filed for returning the item. I thought to give it one more chance before, but this time I did things in different order than the instructions leaflet:
1. Place the pod holder (with the spikes in the bottom) in the NS adapter ring.
2. Place the Nespresso pod in the holder. Press it down into the spikes.
3. Screw on the Nanopresso head on the adapter ring, and then turn upside down so the head is down. Now the back of the pod holder stick out a bit and there is a spring movement.
4. Screw on the Nanopresso body on the adapter kit.
5. Attach the water reservoir and start pumping, a bit more slowly than 1 press per second.

Note that the original instructions are like 1, 3, 2, 4, 5. The important bit in my experience was to make a tight seal on the head first, and then you can make a better total seal by assembling the body last. It also seems to make less stress on the pod's lid.

Even with extreme care, the Nespresso pod lid got a bit torn, but at least all the water pumped through (except a few drops, which is normal).

Coffee quality.
The end result is not as good as the same pod run through a Nespresso machine, but near enough.
Compared to this, making normal espresso with the Nanopresso is a much better experience, the resulting coffee is much better, and it is closer to real espresso than how close you can get to the original Nespresso experience (which is of course less than real espresso).

The Nanopresso gets 5 stars for operation and coffee quality (when making espresso). The Nespresso adapter gets 1 star with original instructions and 3 stars with my instructions on the operation side, and it gets maybe 3 stars on coffee quality side.

I will keep this adapter for the case I want clean coffee making on the road (not too often). Otherwise I recommend making normal espresso with the Nanopresso. For the go, IMHO it's better to buy a Barista kit and take coffee with you prepared (tampered) in the portafilters ( in total 2 double and 2 single shots are possible).

title: Wanted To Love It ... Great In Theory
body:
Background
I was excited about the Nanopresso due to its compact size, and ability to create Espresso drinks just about anywhere. That device, which is not what I'm writing the review for, works pretty well. Time will tell how long the seals / pressure holds up before issues. I then saw this Nanopresso adapter and thought, wow this is even better! Until it wasn't ...

Pros
- The whole system is "modular" meaning you can bolt on additions whether it be a larger water reservoir or in this case the Nespresso Adapter. Very innovative in that sense!
- Easy to use and relatively easy to clean as all parts can be washed ... be careful of the sharp metal parts! Almost cut my finger :)

Cons
- The fit and finish isn't precise. I did notice that Nespresso capsule housing was slightly misaligned. Nothing I can do about it. Probably a machining issue but it didn't appear to affect the performance due to its design.
- Coffee grinds in the cup! A few would be OK. This was more than a few .. maybe at least 25% of the capsule. I looked up whether it is OK to ingest the grinds and it is .. but it is just distracting. I was considering buying a mesh filter to filter out the coffee but then I thought ... "why go through all this hassle and more purchases??"
- Customer service - It is NON EXISTENT. I reached out a couple of times to inquire about the issue and possibly exercise my "30 day money back guarantee" ... but if no one responds then I guess that is just a marketing gimmick.
- CANNOT RETURN! To make matters worse, this is the only product I've encountered where you couldn't click "return". Mind you I tried after 8 days .. and not 30+ days. Nobody responds + no returns = Your own liability & risk. Buyer beware.

I don't know if there is much more I can do on my own to try and make this work. Reading through all the reviews, it looks like the coffee grind thing is not a one-off situation. I have tried the "slow pump" method and even tried relieving the pressure of the capsule in case that is what caused it to "burst" the wrong way .. but nothing seems to prevent the grinds from ending up in my cup. Hope yours is a better experience than mine!

title: Revitalized my faith in the Nanopresso
body:
I'm a real espresso snob. I roast my own beans and have a prosumer machine at home. I won't step foot in a Starbucks. I've owned the Nanopresso for over two years now and have had a love-hate relationship with it. It's frustrating with how finicky the Barista kit double basket can be. Even minor changes to grind, volume, and roast can lead to a complete fail. I was getting very tired of taking the Nanopresso traveling with my wife because of the inconsistency, as well as the time it takes to hand grind. So, I decided to give the NS adaptor a try. After all, consistency should be much better with capsules, and the grinding is already done for me, right?

So, I just tried it out on the cheapo Target brand capsules, since that's all I could find while I wait for some more premium stuff to ship in, and I have to say: I'm floored. The quality of the espresso rivals my $2500 Italian machine. Crema, taste, body, etc. is all on point. And it was so easy and quick. I'll be able to make 4 shots with this in the time it used to take me to just hand grind a single shot. And cleanup is easy with no mess or fuss with grinds.

With the NS adaptor, I'm once again excited to take my Nanopresso traveling. Wish I had done this a year ago.

With adapter attached, this does not fit into the case that I bought for my nanopresso. It will fit if you remove the outer drinking cup. Yes, definitely recommended for traveling. Love the pods.
